{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3602536,"name":"Sean Ernstes","username":"FunkyChicken","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/funkychicken/{size}/239801_2.png","created_at":"2025-04-24T15:58:27.783Z","cooked":"

Preface

On behalf of the maintainers and project managers of QuestNav, I would like to thank all of the FIRST teams that used QuestNav, contributed to it in any way, or even expressed interest this season. As a community driven solution, any form of support helps us.

Our Mission

During the FIRST Championship, some teams expressed their concern over the availability of Meta Quests in regions where it is not officially sold. QuestNav was created with the purpose to expand the availability of cheap, high quality localization to all teams. Not just those in countries where Quests are sold. As such, we are announcing today that we have decided to explore expanding support to the Pico 4, which is officially sold in China, and is available in many other nations as well.

Documentation

Today, we are also announcing the release of comprehensive documentation for version v0.9 of QuestNav. This should help clear up a lot of frequently asked questions. The site is available at https://questnav.gg now! A lot will be changing between now and 2026, as such, documentation on this rolling release cycle may be delayed. We encourage teams to try QuestNav but be prepared for changes as we implement them.

Support

In order to better assist teams, we are recommending people join our discord instead of using CD for support due to its real-time nature. Join here.

What is Changing?

AprilTag Support

After the 2025 season, many teams expressed interest in using the AprilTags on the field for initialization of QuestNav’s pose and validation of the VSLAM pose during the match. With the recent release of Meta’s Passthrough Camera API, we can utilize this along with the Spatial Anchoring API to provide a consistent and performant fiducial detector. This completely eliminates the need for any external devices that many teams previously used like LimeLights or PhotonVision. We expect this to remove the issues of human error in resetting the start pose, as well as accounting for edge cases that may—albeit very rarely—arise during the match.

NetworkTables

Along with this, we plan to improve the connection robustness of the headset by implementing a more up-to-date NetworkTables library, and supporting alternative connection methods.

Debugging

In the coming months we will be releasing a web-based log viewer for teams to easily debug any issues that may occur during use. This will also make it significantly easier to provide community support and hopefully allow us to assist more teams.

More

We expect some other miscellaneous changes to be made as well, but we wanted to outline the major ones. Be sure to keep an eye on the project roadmap and be sure to open an issue on GitHub if you have a feature suggestion!

Wrap-up

We will be providing updates in this thread as new features are implemented and released to keep everyone informed. We hope to see a lot of Quests next year!

Best,

Sean
5152 Lead Programmer & QuestNav PM
FRC Team 5152 - Alotobots

@juchong

Ernstes","username":"FunkyChicken","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/funkychicken/{size}/239801_2.png","created_at":"2025-04-24T20:20:33.062Z","cooked":"

One other notable item I forgot to mention!

Officially, we have begun migrating our recommended method of resetting the Quest’s pose to a field position. Now, we recommend you use the built-in API to reset the pose of the Quest on the Quest side. This differs from our previous method of resetting the pose with an offset on the robot code side.

This can be easily switched, and is documented in our new documentation!
See here.

This change is highly recommended as we move towards getting AprilTag compatibility for various reasons, most notably it allows the Quest to maintain its own state, rather than being dependent on the robot code.

Happy Questing!

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":8,"updated_at":"2025-04-24T20:20:33.062Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":3,"reads":463,"readers_count":462,"score":307.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":500390,"topic_slug":"questnav-whats-next","display_username":"Sean Ernstes","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://questnav.gg/docs/getting-started/robot-code#setting-robot-pose","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Robot Code Setup | QuestNav","clicks":35}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":13}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":69830,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Dev Team Lead | QuestNav PM"},"post_url":"/t/questnav-whats-next/500390/2","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":13}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":13,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3609974,"name":"Andy Gasser","username":"gdefender","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/gdefender/{size}/168507_2.png","created_at":"2025-05-02T19:14:07.888Z","cooked":"

Is there any concern about the latency of doing it this way? It seems like it would only be recommended to reset the pose when the robot is sitting still.

For example, at the start of auto with PathPlanner, it calls the method to reset the pose to the starting pose of the auto. Then it immediately start running the first path. If the new pose is asynchronously sent to the QuestNav, the robot will be moving by the time the pose is actually reset on the Quest side.

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":8,"updated_at":"2025-05-02T19:14:07.888Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":4,"reads":370,"readers_count":369,"score":113.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":500390,"topic_slug":"questnav-whats-next","display_username":"Andy Gasser","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":69830,"username":"FunkyChicken","name":"Sean Ernstes","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/funkychicken/{size}/239801_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":44380,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"7028 - Java Programming Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/questnav-whats-next/500390/3","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3610108,"name":"Sean Ernstes","username":"FunkyChicken","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/funkychicken/{size}/239801_2.png","created_at":"2025-05-02T20:34:45.076Z","cooked":"

Of course, latency will always be an issue. We are doing some items to mitigate it however.

We are in the process of switching over to natively run NetworkTables on the Quest side, which will give us significantly faster response and loop times. Along with this, we are transitioning to using protobufs for the command frames, which will include timestamps for latency compensation.

You can also “fix” this issue before the native NetworkTable release is ready by doing something like this:

Some code from 5152’s 2025 repo

    // Add listener for auto path changes
    autoChooser.getSendableChooser().onChange(this::handleAutoPathChange);

  private void handleAutoPathChange(String autoName) {
    pathPlannerManager
        .getAutoStartPose(autoName)
        .ifPresent(
            pose -> {
              swerveDriveSubsystem.setPose(pose);
              oculusSubsystem.resetPose(pose);
            });
  }

Here is the link to the getAutoStartPose method

This essentially just resets the auto start pose whenever the new auto is selected, rather than when the auto starts.

Obviously not a perfect solution, but it should be a stopgap until we can get the new version working! The main reason why this switch is necessary as a whole is due to AprilTag detection as stated previously. You don’t necessarily have to switch yet, but it may be advantageous for your team to do it prior to the AprilTag feature’s release.

Gasser","username":"gdefender","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/gdefender/{size}/168507_2.png","created_at":"2025-05-02T20:43:51.847Z","cooked":"

I ran into two things in the documentation, and I’m not sure if they warrant creating a bug.

I started with this info from the documentation: Updating Swerve Drive Pose

  1. I did not have much success with fusing odometry with QuestNav poses until I also raised the standard deviations for the drivetrain. This took a little work to figure out, but it can be done by calling a different constructor in TunerConstants.
  2. CTRE does use a different timestamp, and this is kind of a problem, but starting in Tuner X 2025.3.1.0 the generated CommandSwerveDrivetrain has an AddVisionMeasurement overide that already handles this. I just copy/pasted the code from the example and then realized it was calling Utils.fpgaToCurrentTime twice. You should either mention that, or call super.addVisionMeasurement in the example to be safe.

I went ahead and created a GitHub issue for the documentation issue. I wrote all of the documentation and our team switched away from using CTRE swerve template this year, so I was still working with last year’s knowledge.

I should be able to get it fixed pretty soon. As for the odometry fusing, I will have to look into that. Feel free to make a GitHub issue if the way you solved it is working and I’ll write up the documentation.

Also, any chance you could join the Discord? It is much easier from a support standpoint!

FunkyChicken:

Join here.

How was the conclusion reached that structured light (such as the IR line projectors on some models of the Quest) doesn’t help in accuracy?

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":8,"updated_at":"2025-06-14T02:09:19.711Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":222,"readers_count":221,"score":49.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":500390,"topic_slug":"questnav-whats-next","display_username":"viggy96","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":24613,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"418 Mentor | Tries to be smart"},"post_url":"/t/questnav-whats-next/500390/7","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3659368,"name":"Sean Ernstes","username":"FunkyChicken","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/funkychicken/{size}/239801_2.png","created_at":"2025-06-21T19:34:14.124Z","cooked":"

QuestNav v2025-1.0.0-beta is now out!

What’s Changed

  • NetworkTables implementation is now fully run in native code making it much more stable, quicker to connect, and lower latency
  • Protocol Buffers are now used to send and receive data in a more efficient, sterilized, and structured format.
  • App timings have been adjusted to limit the rate at which non critical things (e.g. logging) happen, significantly improving efficiency (internal battery now lasts around 2hr 20m from initial testing)
  • Vendor dependency, QuestNavLib was created for the robot code side of things to make it easier for teams to implement
  • A couple of other miscellaneous things

Full Changelog: v0.9.0…v2025-1.0.0-beta

Why is this a beta release?

Although we have done significant testing already, We would like more teams to test it before we deem it tried and true. There are a few known issues with the current build, but nothing critical. It is definitely an improvement over the previous version, however!

Migration from v0.9.0

To migrate from older versions we recommend you simply start fresh and follow the updated quick-start documentation again due to the amount of changes.

Robot Code Setup Link

Known Issues

  • getLatency method is only accurate for a small amount of time after the robot code starts, then starts slowly drifting towards a more negative value

How you can Help

If you find an issue, get support in the Discord and create a GitHub issue.

Thanks again for the support, and happy Quest-ing!

LINK TO RELEASE
